title: 1274 Index

Page 1295

1274 Index

Insertion Sort

Sort cards in your hand one at a time

Imagine sorting a hand of playing cards. You pick up one card at a time and insert it into its correct position among the cards you've already sorted.

How It Works

  1. Start with the second element (first is 'sorted')
  2. Compare current element with sorted elements to its left
  3. Shift larger elements right to make room
  4. Insert the element in its correct position
  5. Repeat for all remaining elements

Complexity

  • Time Best: O(n) - already sorted
  • Time Avg: O(n²)
  • Time Worst: O(n²) - reverse sorted
  • Space: O(1) - in-place

When to Use

  • Small arrays (< 50 elements)
  • Nearly sorted data
  • Online sorting (data arrives one at a time)
  • Simple implementation needed

Merge Sort

Divide in half, sort each half, merge them

Split a deck of cards in half, sort each half separately, then merge them by always picking the smaller top card from each pile.

How It Works

  1. Divide array into two halves
  2. Recursively sort left half
  3. Recursively sort right half
  4. Merge the two sorted halves

Complexity

  • Time Best: O(n log n)
  • Time Avg: O(n log n)
  • Time Worst: O(n log n)
  • Space: O(n) - needs extra array

When to Use

  • Guaranteed O(n log n) needed
  • Linked lists (no random access needed)
  • External sorting (large files)
  • Stable sort needed
